instruction: The input is taken from a negotiation between two participants who take the role of campsite neighbors and negotiate for Food, Water, and Firewood packages, based on their individual preferences and requirements. Given an utterance and recent dialogue context containing past 3 utterances (wherever available), output Yes if the utterance contains the elicit-pref strategy, otherwise output No. elicit-pref is a cooperative negotiation strategy. It is used to discover the preference order of the opponent in the negotiation.
input:
Context: 'Definitely! I am glad we could come to an agreement. Do you like to camp a lot? Or hike?' 'I love to camp! Especially when there is enough firewood! It is a great (and inexpensive) activity for me I get a lot of enjoyment out of. Hopefully you will become an avid camper after this trip!' 'Haha maybe! I am afraid of some bugs though, especially ticks 😮'
Utterance: 'Yes, you have to check EVERYWHERE for ticks! And since we've come to an agreement, I will submit our deal!'

instruction: The input is taken from a negotiation between two participants who take the role of campsite neighbors and negotiate for Food, Water, and Firewood packages, based on their individual preferences and requirements. It is used to discover the preference order of the opponent in the negotiation.
input:
Context: 'Hey there fellow camper! How's it going? ' 'Hey camper buddy! all goes well. and you?'
Utterance: 'All is good. Could you tell me about your package preferences?'

instruction: The input is taken from a negotiation between two participants who take the role of campsite neighbors and negotiate for Food, Water, and Firewood packages, based on their individual preferences and requirements. Given an utterance and recent dialogue context containing past 3 utterances (wherever available), output Yes if the utterance contains the elicit-pref strategy, otherwise output No. elicit-pref is a cooperative negotiation strategy. It is used to discover the preference order of the opponent in the negotiation.
input:
Context: 'That sounds amazing and delicious! maybe we can compromise? Maybe, I can get all 3 waters and you can have all 3 Foods? what do you think? ' ' I would agree to that if I can also have two things of firewood. I am going to need a lot of wood, so I can cook the meals I am making 🙂' 'I completely understand, thank you for compromising with water and food. Wished we had 4 firewoods to divide and share it equaly, may I ask how long will you be camping for? Im afraid I need 2 firewoods as well, maybe we can see who has the greater need? '
Utterance: 'I am going to be camping for a couple of weeks, so I will need quite a bit. I also realized some additional water would be good, because I have some meals that need me to boil water. Maybe you can have 2 firewood in exchange for me having one of your waters? Then you would still have plenty of water, but also plenty of firewood 🙂'

instruction: The input is taken from a negotiation between two participants who take the role of campsite neighbors and negotiate for Food, Water, and Firewood packages, based on their individual preferences and requirements. input:
Context: 'Its good! I am looking forward to the activites i'll be doing, such as campfires.' 'Hey, that's great. Good to hear definitely. I am also looking forward to build some campfires and enjoy some s'mores!' 'Thats great! Would it be okay if I got 2 packages of firewood, and 1 each of the food and water?'
Utterance: 'I would've like to have 2 packages of firewood instead. How about I give you all the extra water packages?'

Context: 'Sry for the extra emoticons, laptop's glitching apparently. Well, what can you give me or we come to a deal on? 🙂' 'Well, let me think on that.  Why do you need so much water for a starter?' 'I get dehydrated easily. I need to water so that doesn't happen. 🙂'
Utterance: 'Hmm.  And why do you need so much food?'

Utterance: 'Hello! And happy camping! 🙂 To start off, I am thinking that I will need at least 3 firewood, 2 water and 1 food. Last time my axe broke and we ran out of wood! What do you think/need?'
